Introduction

The DuPont corporation is a member of the American Chemistry Council and receives external certification of its' Responsible Care Management System (RCMS) consistent with those requirements.  The DuPont Washington Works site adheres to Corporate Safety Health and Environmental (SHE) policies.  For safety and environmental incidents, these policies could be summarized as follows:

  -We believe all safety and environmental incidents are preventable.

  -Our goal for incidents is zero.

  -We are prepared for emergencies and we will provide assistance to our local communities to help in their emergency preparedness.

Corporate Safety, Health and Environmental (SHE) policies and RCMS policies are embodied in numerous site SHE procedures along with guidelines and recommended practices in DuPont Engineering Standards. Corporate SHE policies and Washington Works SHE procedures are available for review by all employees.

At Washington Works, SHE policies and procedures are also documented in the Washington Works SHE Manual.  Various procedures throughout the manual deal specifically with Process Safety Management elements to prevent incidents from occurring.  It is the responsibility of every employee and contractor working on our behalf to comply with these procedures.  It is management's responsibility to educate and train employees so they may understand and comply with the procedures. 



Facility Description

The DuPont Washington Works facility is a tenant of The Chemours Company FC, LLC located approximately five miles south of Parkersburg, WV.  DuPont manufacturing operations are located on approximately 65 acres.  Polymer resins and products in primary forms are manufactured at the site.  

The site uses the following EPA regulated RMP chemicals at levels above their process threshold quantities:

               Toxics - formaldehyde



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The Washington Works site man

ufacturing areas follow the requirements set out in DuPont Corporate SHE Standard S21A, Process Safety Management.  This standard includes and embraces the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR Part 68.  The standard involves the following activities as listed below: 



Safety in Design...

- A documented process technology system covers hazards of materials, equipment design basis, and process design basis.

- Extensive active and passive preventative and mitigating systems are strategically located.

- Applicable codes and standards are met or exceeded.

- Materials of construction are chosen to provide mechanical integrity.

- Quality Assurance ensures fabrication in accordance with design specifications and proper assembly.



Safety in Maintenance...

 - Maintenance personnel are trained and experienced.

- Contractors are trained and qualified.

- A work permit system controls hazards.



Safety in Operations...

- Operators are trained and job qualified.

- Technical resources are available and utilized as required.

- Operators follow approved procedures.



Safety through Reviews, Inspections, Process Hazards Analysis, Investigation and Auditing...

- Routine safety inspections are conducted.

- Corporate and independent audits and reviews are conducted.

- Process Hazards Analyses are conducted.

- Safety critical equipment is set up on a periodic inspection frequency to ensure ongoing mechanical integrity.

- Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted prior to starting up any new or modified equipment.

- Quality assurance of critical equipment ensures fabrication in accordance with design specifications.

- All incidents are investigated and actions taken to prevent recurrence. 



These individual activities encompass the parts of our RMP prevention program and we have established specific controls to ensure that we are meeting these standards to prevent accidental releases.



Five-year Accident History

There have been no RMP recordable accidents

at the DuPont Washington Works facility during the past five years.



Emergency Response Program

The site emergency response program is documented in the Washington Works Emergency Control Organization (ECO) Manual and is available for review by all employees.  The Emergency Response Program in place at Washington Works is such that emergency response is provided by the landlord, The Chemours Company FC, LLC.  DuPont area personnel are a part of the site's emergency response team and actively participate in drills and emergencies.  The emergency response personnel are trained and equipped to respond to accidental chemical releases.  The program can be summarized as follows:



Training and preparation

  -Plant personnel and emergency responders receive emergency response training.

  -Emergency response plans are periodically reviewed and updated.

  -The plant conducts periodic emergency drills, including critiques.

  -A plant representative actively participates on the Wood County Local Emergency Planning Committees (LEPC).



If a release with the potential for off-site impact occurs:

 -The plant emergency alarm is sounded.

 -The plant Emergency Control Organization (ECO) Headquarters is activated.

 -Plant emergency personnel respond.

 -Community responders are notified and asked to respond as appropriate.

 -The local Industrial Alert System is activated if warranted.



Programs detailing emergency responder training and emergency equipment maintenance can be found in the Washington Works S&OH manual, ECO manual, and computer-based training programs.  All of these activities are monitored to ensure they remain current.  



Planned Changes To Improve Safety

Making our processes safer is an on-going program at DuPont Washington Works.  Employee suggestions, capital improvements, audit programs, and various other activities help to ensure that we provide safe, reliable processes. Other programs aimed at improving process safety and our emergency response

planning includes:

- Recommendations developed during cyclic process hazards analyses that reduce the risks associated with our processes.

 - Providing additional process safety training to technical personnel in topics such as chemical reactivity, layer of protection analysis, and safety instrumented systems risk analysis.
